author: Anjani Trivedi
title: Asian Development Bank's regional gloom deepens - MarketWatch
text:
HONG KONG--Worse-than-expected economic growth in the first half for most Asian economies and a delayed global recovery has led the Asian Development Bank to cut its regional forecasts for this year and next.
The region's GDP will grow 5.8% in 2015 and 6.0% in 2016--down in both cases from 6.3% previously forecast--the Manila-based development lender said in a report Tuesday.
As investor confidence in developing Asia's growth prospects fades, capital is flowing out--drawn to the U.S., with its prospect of higher interest rates and better growth--and currencies are depreciating, amplifying the troubles for policy makers seeking to shore up growth while maintaining financial stability.
"Global headwinds could further abrade the region's growth path," the ADB said in the 214-page "Asian Development Outlook 2015 Update: Enabling Women, Energizing Asia."
Subdued demand from major economies has stifled Asian export growth, while planned infrastructure investment in some countries has fallen behind schedule.
Companies in the region with foreign-currency debt burdens and limited foreign currency revenues will face rising debt-service costs as the U.S. dollar strengthens, the ADB warned, urging policy makers to look at measures to limit volatile capital flows that could destabilize economies and "brace their economies for the headwinds to come."
Developing Asian economies closely linked with China need to explore "new avenues," the report said, adjusting to slower Chinese growth driven more by domestic consumption and less by investment. The ADB cut China's growth forecast for this year to 6.8% from 7.2%.
A slowdown in the region's growth powerhouse is expected to hurt developing Asia "directly through reduced trade and indirectly through lower commodity prices," the report's authors wrote. Striking a hopeful note, the bank said as a recovery in major industrial economies takes hold, downward pressure on China could ease.
Expectations that India, the region's second-largest economy, would provide a bounce to developing Asia's growth as China retreats, have waned as planned reforms stay stuck in low gear.
"Unfortunately, India is not yet in a position to pick up the slack in demand from a moderating [China]," the ADB report said.
The region's falling growth forecasts highlight the need to "identify untapped resources in the region." Narrowing gender gaps in the region's labor markets could bolster growth. Bringing more women into the labor force could increase per capita income by 70% in roughly 60 years, the bank estimates.
